N-doped Co3O4 catalyst with a high efficiency for the catalytic decomposition of N2O Xiaobo Hu a b Yongzhao Wang a ⁎ Ruifang Wu a Yongxiang Zhao a ⁎ a Engineering Research Center of Ministry of Education for Fine Chemicals, Shanxi University, Taiyuan 030006, China Engineering Research Center of Ministry of Education for Fine Chemicals Shanxi University Taiyuan 030006 China aEngineering Research Center of Ministry of Education for Fine Chemicals, Shanxi University, Taiyuan 030006, China b School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shanxi University, Taiyuan 030006, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shanxi University Taiyuan 030006 China bSchool of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shanxi University, Taiyuan 030006, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. A series of defective N-doped Co3O4 catalysts, N-Co3O4-x (x = 0.002, 0.01, 0.05, 0.15, and 0.25), were prepared by a facile graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4)-modified sol-gel method, and their catalytic behaviors for N2O decomposition reaction were evaluated. The activity tests indicated that all the N-Co3O4-x catalysts showed superior activity than the pristine Co3O4, and N-Co3O4–0.05 exhibited the best activity with 100% N2O conversion at a reaction temperature of 380 °C, ca. 160 °C lower than that of Co3O4. N-Co3O4–0.05 also showed high catalytic activity and stability in the presence of impurity gasses (O2, NO, and/or H2O) at varying reaction conditions. Based on the employed systematic characterization techniques, the successful doping of N atoms into Co3O4 was confirmed. The N-doping facilitated more defective structures (namely oxygen vacancies), surface Co2+, and basic sites on Co3O4. In addition, N-doping contributed to enlarging the surface area, improving the electron donation ability of Co2+, enhancing the redox property of Co3O4, and weakening the Co-O bond. All these factors promoted the performance of N-Co3O4–0.05 for N2O decomposition. This work provides a simple strategy to construct advanced N-doped Co3O4 material for N2O decomposition applications and other catalytic reactions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Co3O4 g-C3N4 N doping Defects Decomposition of N2O Introduction Nitrous oxides (N2O), produced from anthropogenic sources such as fertilization, sewage treatment, biomass/fossil fuels combustion, and chemical processing, is an inevitable hazardous component of exhaust gasses [1–3]. Statistics show that the exhaust gasses from chemical industries for the manufacture of adipic acid and nitric acid contain 20–50 vol.% and 0.03–0.35 vol.% N2O, respectively, while those from mobile sources released by three-way catalytic converters (TWCs) contains less than 0.1 vol.% N2O, and fluidized bed combustion contains 0.005–0.05 vol.% N2O [2]. Being a greenhouse gas, N2O has caused tremendous environmental damages, which is evidenced by the depletion of ozone layer and exacerbation of the greenhouse effect [2,4]. Furthermore, it is noteworthy that N2O is very stable in the earth's atmosphere with a lifetime of 110–150 years [5]. Therefore, its effective removal has become an important and urgent task in order to protect the environment. Recently, manifold applicable technologies, such as thermal decomposition, catalytic decomposition, and catalytic reduction, have been investigated for the removal of N2O [7]. Among them, the direct catalytic decomposition process has attracted the most attention because of its easy operation, high efficiency, and environmental friendliness [6]. Although the direct catalytic decomposition of N2O (deN2O) is thermodynamically favored, the reaction is kinetically hindered (Eq. (I)) [7,8]. Therefore, the choice of catalyst materials with abilities to effectively break the N-O bond is a very important step in the deN2O reaction. A variety of catalyst systems have been developed for deN2O, such as noble metal-containing catalysts [9,10], metal-ion exchanged zeolites [11,12], metal oxides like perovskites [13], spinels [14–19], hexaferrites [20], and mixed oxides derived from hydrotalcites [21,22]. Specifically, due to its high redox ability and weak Co-O bond, the cost-effective spinel cobalt oxide (Co3O4) with excellent deN2O activity has been considered as an excellent candidate for N2O removal [23]. (1) 2 N 2 O → 2 N 2 + O 2 ( Δ r H 0 ( 298 K ) = − 163 kJ mo l − 1 , Ea = 250 kJ mo l − 1 ) Generally, there is an inevitable co-existence of water vapor (H2O), O2, and/or NO as contaminants in the exhaust gas. These contaminants from the reactant stream cause significant deactivation of the Co3O4 catalyst [14–16]. However, the Co3O4 catalyst has a high likelihood to sinter with reaction time even in the absence of the contaminants [7,15,16]. Hence, the development of suitable Co3O4-based catalysts with high activity, good stability, and strong contaminant resistance for deN2O remains a challenging task. As published elsewhere, the deN2O reaction over Co3O4 proceeds via two kinds of redox mechanisms: mechanism I, Eq. (2)-(4), and mechanism II, Eq. (5)-(6) [15,17,24,69]. It is obvious that the relative amount of Co2+ or Ovac for adsorbing N2O (Ovac refers to oxygen vacancies), Co-O bond strength, the electron donation tendency of Co2+, and Co2+ ↔ Co3+ redox potential for Co3O4 are key factors in the deN2O reaction. Based on these factors, several investigations have been conducted to explore low cost and efficient Co3O4-based catalysts. They found that the deN2O activity of Co3O4 can be boosted by different types of modifications, mainly in doping a small amount of alkali metals like K and Cs [25,65,66], alkali earth metals like Ca and Ba [26,27], and other oxides like CeO2, TiO2, PbO2, Y2O3, and SnO2 into a Co3O4 spinel [7,14–16,18,64]. Despite these improvements, there are still very interesting prospects for the enhancement of the activity of Co3O4. (2) N 2 O + C o 2 + → N 2 + C o 3 + O − (3) 2 C o 3 + O − → O 2 + 2 C o 2 + (4) C o 3 + O − + N 2 O → C o 2 + + N 2 + O 2 (5) C o 2 + − Ovac + N 2 O → C o 3 + − O − + N 2 (6) C o 3 + − O − → C o 2 + − Ovac + O 2 In recent years, metal-free hetero-atom doping, such as N-doping, has been proven to be a facile and efficient method for modulating the surface structures and electronic properties of the nanomaterials [28–30,58]. For instance, Wei et al. reported that N-S-co-doped TiO2 was highly effective towards catalytic methyl orange decomposition, and this improvement was attributed to the creation of surface oxygen vacancies and the increase of surface acidity [28]. Wang et al. reported excellent performance for direct deNO by N-doped porous carbon owing to the rich Lewis bases on its surface could achieve [29]. Yu and coworkers reported that the possibility of oxygen vacancies production on the surface of CoOx/N-doped CeO2 which improves its reduction property. This is an important step in the enhancement of oxidation performance of NO [30]. Xu et al. found that N-doped nanoporous Co3O4 nanosheets with abundant oxygen vacancies showed advanced electrocatalytic performance for the OER [58]. N having a similar atomic radius with O, completely exhibits a comparatively different electronegativity; thus, it is logical to expect that doping N into Co3O4 provides a great chance for creating anionic defects and introducing oxygen vacancies. Meanwhile, the N dopant can influence the charge distribution of adjacent Co and O atoms, causing the weaken of Co-O bond and the improvement of oxygen mobility [31]. Based on the aforementioned considerations, the effect of N-doping presents attractive prospects in improving the deN2O activity of Co3O4. Additionally, to the best of our knowledge, there is limited information on investigations involving N-doped Co3O4 catalysts for deN2O. Although some reports have described the feasibility of this process, the complexity of the method, time consideration, and cost of operation, are some of the fundamental challenges yet to be addressed [28,29,31,58]. In our attempt to solve these challenges, a convenient g-C3N4 modified sol-gel method was used in this work. g-C3N4 is a metal-free material with surface functionalities, that is both N-rich and electron-rich. It has attracted interdisciplinary attention in diverse fields including photocatalysts [32,33], transesterification [34], and fuel cells [35]. In the present work, this special material has been used for the first time as an N source to synthesize defective N-Co3O4-x (x = 0.002, 0.01, 0.05, 0.15, and 0.25) catalysts via the sol-gel method, and their catalytic behaviors for deN2O reaction were evaluated. The as-prepared N-Co3O4–0.05 sample exhibited improved activity, higher stability, and stronger resistance to impurity gasses than its un-doped counterpart. A series of analytical techniques were applied to characterize the physicochemical properties associated with the excellent catalytic activities of the N-doped Co3O4 catalysts. Based on the findings herein, we believe that N-doped Co3O4 catalyst can be effectively applied as a novel, active, and scalable material with outstanding potentials in environmental remediation. Experimental Materials The reagent of melamine (C3H6N6) was purchased from Tianjin Dingshengxin Chemical Co., Ltd (China). The reagent of citric acid (C6H8O7) was got from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd (China). The reagent of cobalt nitrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O) was bought from Tianjin Damao Chemical Reagent Factory (China). All the reagents were used as received without further purification. Catalyst preparation g-C3N4 was obtained from the melamine by thermal condensation. Typically, 5 g melamine was put into a covered crucible which was first heated in air at 500 °C for 2 h and was further heated in air at 520 °C for 2 h with a heating rate 4 °C min−1. The solid obtained was collected and ground into fine powder for further use. The amount of g-C3N4 finally produced was 0.35 g. The preparation of N-doped Co3O4 catalysts were achieved by a g-C3N4-modified citrate sol-gel method. Take synthetic N-Co3O4–0.01 as an example, first of all, 10.8787 g Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 10.7722 g C6H8O7 were dissolved in 75 mL distilled water at room temperature and vigorously stirred for 0.5 h. Subsequently, 0.0374 g g-C3N4 power was dispersed into the above solution and left to stir for another 1 h. After that the temperature was increased to 90 °C to remove the water-solvent via evaporation until a viscous gel was formed. The viscous gel was dried in a blast drying oven at 120 °C for 12 h and then calcined in air in a crucible at 500 °C for 4 h with a heating rate 4 °C min−1. The obtained samples were labeled as N-Co3O4-x (x represents the theoretical N/Co atomic ratio, x = 0.002, 0.01, 0.05, 0.15, and 0.25), with the weight of g-C3N4 in raw materials 0.0075, 0.0374, 0.1869, 0.5607, and 0.9345 g, respectively. N-undoped Co3O4 catalyst was also prepared by using the above protocol for comparison and denoted as Co3O4. Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were acquired on a Bruker D8 Advance apparatus with Cu Kα radiation using silicon reference. FT-IR spectra were recorded between 400 and 4000 cm−1 with a Bruker Tensor 27 FT-IR system. Raman spectroscopy was recorded on a LabRAM HR Evolution Raman spectrograph, YAG laser wavelength of 532 nm. N2-physisorption analysis was achieved with a Micromeritics ASAP-2020 apparatus. All samples were previously outgassed at 200 °C for 5 h. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) measurement was observed in a JEM-2100 with the acceleration voltage of 200 kV. Surface morphology and composition of the sample were observed through the use of a high-angle annular dark field-scanning transmission electron microscopy (HADDF-STEM, HD-2700, HITACHI Ltd.) equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectroscope (EDX). Conductivity test was performed on an electrochemical workstation (Shanghai Chenhua Chi660e). X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were obtained on a PHI 5600 Multi Technique System. The binding energies for all the samples were referenced to the C 1s core level (284.6 eV) from hydrocarbon contaminations. H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) profiles were measured on a Micromeritics AutoChemII 2920 analyzer. 30 mg of sample was loaded in a quartz U-shape reactor. TPR profiles were recorded in flowing 5 vol.% H2/N2 (30 mL min−1) with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. O2 pulse adsorption and temperature programmed desorption (O2-TPD) were carried out by using the Chem BET Pulsar TPR/TPD. For each experiment, 100 mg of sample was placed in a quartz reactor, followed by pretreated in situ at 300 °C for 30 min in flowing He (40 mL min−1). After that it was cooled down to 100 °C. Subsequently, O2 was injected in pulse until saturated adsorption was reached, and then the sample was cooled down to 50 °C in He, to start the O2-TPD in flowing He from 50 °C to 700 °C (heating rate 10 °C min−1). Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurements were performed on a Bruker A-300 electron paramagnetic resonance spectrometer. The apparatus used for CO2-TPD was identical to that of O2-TPD. Before test, 100 mg of sample was first treated at 300 °C for 1 h in flowing He (40 mL min−1) and then cooled down to 50 °C. Subsequently, CO2 pulse adsorption was carried out over the sample until saturated adsorption was reached, to start the CO2-TPD in flowing He from 50 °C to 700 °C (heating rate 10 °C min−1). Catalytic tests The catalytic deN2O test was performed on a fixed-bed flow microreactor operated under atmospheric pressure. Fig. 1 shows the schematic diagram of the activity estimation apparatus. In a typical experiment, 300 mg of catalyst (sieve fraction of 40–60 mesh, no further pretreatment) was loaded in the center of the reactor (4 mm i.d.) with quartz-wool plugs. The sample was sieved to 40–60 mesh in order that temperature gradients and pressure drop over the catalyst bed were negligible. The reactant gas mixture (1000 ppm N2O with or without 3 vol.% O2, 3.3 vol.% H2O, and/or 200 ppm NO, Ar balance) was fed to the reactor. The gas flow of each component was adjusted by a mass flow instrument. Here, a total gas flow of 50 ml min−1 was used, which corresponded to a gas hour space velocity (GHSV) of 10,000 h− 1. The concentrations of N2O in the tail gas and feed gas were analyzed on-line by an Agilent 7890 B gas chromatograph (columns: PoraPLOT Q and HP-MOLESIEVE) equipped with a thermal conducting detector (TCD). The N2O conversion is defined as: (8) N 2 O conversion ( % ) = [ N 2 O ] in − [ N 2 O ] out [ N 2 O ] in × 100 ( % ) where [N2O]in and [N2O]out represent the inlet and outlet N2O concentrations, respectively. As published elsewhere, the deN2O reaction obeys first order kinetics [18,67]. In the present work, the Weisz-Prater criterion was applied to assess the impact of internal mass transport limitations. The influence of different GHSV on deN2O catalytic performance was carried out to assess the impact of externa mass transport limitations. The results, shown in Supporting Information, confirmed that both external mass transport and internal mass transport resistance could be neglected during reaction. The conditions selected in the work could avoid the transport phenomena limitation in the catalyst evaluation experiments. For kinetic parameters, reaction rate (r) and rate constant (k) as well as activation energy (Ea) were obtained based on the equations (2′)-(4′). Turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated according to the equation (5’) (see Supporting Information). Results and discussion Catalytic activity (For the feed gas of 1000 ppm N2O/Ar) The catalytic activities of the pristine Co3O4 and N-Co3O4-x (x = 0.002, 0.01, 0.05, 0.15, and 0.25) catalysts were studied under the adopted conditions, and the temperatures of 50% and 90% (T50 and T90) were used as the measurement indexes. As presented in Fig. 2 , Co3O4 showed low catalytic activity of T50 at 460 °C and T90 at 520 °C. After N-doping of Co3O4, the deN2O activities of N-Co3O4-x were enhanced. However, the promotion effect was strongly dependent on the amount of doped N. The deN2O activities over these catalysts followed the sequence N-Co3O4–0.05 > N-Co3O4–0.01 > N-Co3O4–0.15 ≈ N-Co3O4–0.25 > N-Co3O4–0.002 ≈ Co3O4. Obviously, the N-Co3O4–0.05 sample exhibited the highest activity for deN2O in this series, by achieving T50 at 320 °C and T90 at 360 °C. These were much lower than those of Co3O4. The above test results sufficiently demonstrate the superiority of N-Co3O4–0.05 catalyst for deN2O. Characterization of the catalysts From the above catalytic activity results (Fig. 2), N-Co3O4–0.002 and N-Co3O4–0.15 showed similar activities to Co3O4 and N-Co3O4–0.25, respectively. Thus, a series of characterization tests will concentrate on the structure, texture, and surface properties of the representative samples, Co3O4, N-Co3O4–0.01, N-Co3O4–0.05, and N-Co3O4–0.15. XRD analysis Fig. 3 illustrates the XRD patterns of the pristine Co3O4, N-Co3O4-x (x = 0.01, 0.05, and 0.15), and g-C3N4 samples. In the case of g-C3N4, two broad peaks at 2θ values of 13.1 and 27.5°, corresponding to the (002) and (100) diffraction planes, were observed [36]. For the N-Co3O4-x catalysts, no reflections for g-C3N4 were present in these samples. The pristine Co3O4 and N-Co3O4-x catalysts presented almost identical XRD patterns, and reflections were assigned to the spinel-type Co3O4 oxide (110) 2θ = 18.9°, (220) 2θ = 31.2°, (311) 2θ = 36.9°, (222) 2θ = 38.6°, (400) 2θ = 44.8°, (422) 2θ = 55.6°, (440) 2θ = 59.3°, and (511) 2θ = 65.2° [18], without additional reflections attributed to the Co-N species. Furthermore, the average grain sizes of Co3O4 for these samples were calculated from the spinel diffraction line (311) with the help of Scherrer equation and the results are listed in Table 1 . As can be seen, their values ranged between 22.5 and 24.5 nm, with observed slight changes upon doping N into Co3O4. Table 1 also displays the crystal parameter values of Co3O4 for pristine Co3O4 and N-Co3O4-x catalysts. It can be observed that the values of N-Co3O4-x samples (a = b = c = ~0.8093) were slightly different from that of the pristine Co3O4 (a = b = c = 0.8090) [37], indicating that N atoms can be doped into Co3O4. Also, most of the Co3O4 existed in a crystal form, meaning that the spinel structures were maintained after the N-doping. FT-IR analysis Fig. 4 presents the FT-IR spectra of the pristine Co3O4, N-Co3O4-x (x = 0.01, 0.05, and 0.15), and g-C3N4 samples, and the spectrum for g-C3N4 manifested three main absorption regions. The broad and intense bands at 2800–3650 cm−1 could be assigned to the stretching vibration of N-H of secondary and primary amines and the stretching vibration of O-H of adsorbed H2O molecules. The strong bands of 1200–1650 cm−1 proved the presence of alternating aromatic CN heterocycles, whereas the sharp band observed ca. 806 cm−1 represented the characteristic breathing mode of the s-triazine ring [36]. However, the above-mentioned FT-IR absorption bands were not observed for the N-Co3O4-x samples. This indicates that the crystal structure of g-C3N4 was destroyed by the Co precursor during calcination at 500 °C in air. This observation is in accordance with the results from previous studies [38,39]. The FT-IR spectra of Co3O4 and N-Co3O4-x were largely similar, with the observation of two new stretching bands at 653 and 568 cm−1, corresponding to the Co2+ Td-O and Co3+ Oct-O stretching vibrations [40]. Thus, confirming the formation of Co3O4 in these catalysts. All the results obtained from the FT-IR analysis are consistent with those from XRD analysis. Raman analysis Raman spectroscopy was carried out to further explore the structures of the pristine Co3O4 and N-Co3O4-x (x = 0.01, 0.05, and 0.15) catalysts. As depicted in Fig. 5 , the Raman spectrum of Co3O4 showed five bands which are typical of the spinel structure around 194, 518, 618, 477, and 684 cm−1, and were due to the (3 × F2g + Eg + A1g) vibrational modes [41]. Along the line, the most prominent A1g peak observed at 684 cm−1 was attributed to the octahedral sites CoO6 symmetry while the remaining minor Eg and F2g peaks were associated with the tetrahedral sites CoO4 symmetry [42]. All these Raman feature bands were detected in the spectra of the N-Co3O4-x catalysts, implying that the spinel structures were maintained after N-doping. It is worthy of note that N-doping led to the red shifts of these bands compared with Co3O4, especially the A1g peaks. The shifts for the vibrational modes of N-Co3O4-x indicate the successful doping of N atoms into Co3O4 to form the Co-N bond [43]. Meanwhile, there were observable significant broadening of the A1g peaks of the N-Co3O4-x samples accompanied by obvious reductions of peak intensities, which may have resulted from the change of cobalt oxide composition (change in Co2+/Co3+ ratio) [42,44]. To prove this, the calculation of IF2g/IA1g was done, based on the intensity ratio of the band at 194 cm−1 to that at 684 cm−1. The ratio of IF2g/IA1g over these samples followed the sequence of N-Co3O4–0.15 (0.30) > N-Co3O4–0.05 (0.27) > N-Co3O4–0.01 (0.25) > Co3O4 (0.21), implying that the N-Co3O4-x catalysts had higher concentrations of Co2+ compared to Co3O4. (HR)-TEM and HADDF-STEM analysis From the TEM characterization shown in Fig. 6 (a) and (b), the nanoparticles of the pristine Co3O4 and N-Co3O4–0.05 catalysts exhibited similar spherical morphologies, which were agglomerated. By statistical calculation, the grain sizes of the pristine Co3O4 (ranging from 21 to 27 nm) were similar to those of the N-Co3O4–0.05 sample (ranging from 20 to 26 nm). The findings are in accordance with the XRD results. The HR-TEM images in Fig. 5(a’) and (b’) show that the d-spacing of the Co3O4 nanoparticles were observed at ca. 0.46 and 0.29 nm, which proves that the predominantly exposed crystallographic planes for both catalysts were (111) and (220) [15]. From the HADDF-STEM and EDX mapping images of N-Co3O4–0.05 as shown in Fig. 7 (a)-(f), the Co3O4 nanoparticles exhibited high surface agglomerations, which is consistent with the TEM results. Additionally, a uniform distribution of Co, O, and N elements were observed, and this confirms that the uniform doping of N element in Co3O4. N2-physisorption analysis The porous structures of the pristine Co3O4, N-Co3O4-x (x = 0.01, 0.05, and 0.15), and g-C3N4 samples were investigated by the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms. As shown in Fig. 8 , all the catalysts displayed type IV isotherms as defined by IUPAC [14], and showed typical H3 type loops, meaning that mesopores with narrow slit-like shapes existed in the structures [45]. Furthermore, the corresponding pore size distributions (inset of Fig. 8) of these catalysts exhibited broad peaks in a wider range of 2–60 nm, further demonstrating that the catalysts possessed mesoporous frameworks. The obtained BET surface area (S BET), total pore volume (V total), and average pore diameter (D p) of all the samples are listed in Table 1. The pristine Co3O4 showed a S BET of 6.2 m2 g− 1 and V total of 0.039 cm3 g− 1, which are lower than those of the N-Co3O4-x samples. Additionally, the S BET of the N-Co3O4-x samples increased with increase in x from 0.01 to 0.05, and remained relatively stable with the continuous increase of x to 0.15. As confirmed by the XRD and FT-IR results, the crystal structure of g-C3N4 was completely destroyed; thus, the enlarged S BET and V total of N-Co3O4-x samples may have resulted from the decomposition of the laminar g-C3N4 during the catalyst preparation, thereby generating gas which led to the development of the observed porous structures [30]. All these suggest that N-doping contributed to the increase of S BET and further exposed more surface of Co3O4, which were favorable to the absorption of the reactant gas (N2O); thus, N2O has high accessibility to the active sites. XPS analysis To gain in-depth surface element information of the prepared catalysts, XPS measurements were employed. From the full XPS spectra and N 1s spectra of the pristine Co3O4 and N-Co3O4-x (x = 0.01, 0.05, and 0.15) catalysts as displayed in Fig. S2 and Fig. 9 (C), it is noted that in addition to the Co, O, and C signals, there are recorded N signals for the N-Co3O4-x samples. As shown in Table 2 , the N-doped contents calculated from the XPS results were 1.17, 1.42, and 1.52 at.% for N-Co3O4–0.01, N-Co3O4–0.05, and N-Co3O4–0.15, respectively. However, the calculated values are clearly lower the theoretical values. Compared with the pristine Co3O4, the O contents for these samples decreased from 65.7 to 63.8, 61.4, and 60.1 at.% after the N-doping. Meanwhile, the Co contents increased from 34.3 to 35.0, 37.2, and 38.3 at.%. These values also deviate from the theoretical values. The above results further demonstrate the destruction of the crystal structure of g-C3N4 during the catalyst preparation process, and the effective doping of N atoms in Co3O4 [31]. Fig. 9(A) shows the Co 2p spectra of Co3O4 and N-Co3O4-x samples, and it shows that the Co3O4 catalyst had two characteristic peaks located at ~779.8 and 795.2 eV, which are assigned to the Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 spin-orbit components, respectively [46]. For each spin-orbit component, two broad and weak intensity satellite peaks (Sat. 1 and Sat. 2) at ~789.5 and 804.7 eV, corresponding to the Co2+ species, were detected [47]. Interestingly, the same components were observed for the N-Co3O4-x catalysts. However, the binding energy (BEs) of Co 2p3/2 peaks for N-Co3O4–0.01, N-Co3O4–0.05, and N-Co3O4–0.15 were approximately 0.09, 0.28, and 0.24 eV, respectively, which were lower than that of Co3O4, indicating that N-doping weakened the Co-O bond for the N-Co3O4-x samples, particularly for the N-Co3O4–0.05 sample, just like K or Ag in the K/Co3O4 or Ag-Co3O4 catalyst [48,49]. Considering that the peak fittings of these two components revealed the same surface species, we therefore focused on the analysis of the Co 2p3/2 component in the present study [14]. After deconvolution, two peaks at the BE of ~781.3 and 779.7 eV, assigned to Co2+ and Co3+ species, were observed [7,47,68]. Reports have shown that the molar ratio of Co2+/Co3+ is a reflection of the defects in cobalt oxide, where a higher ratio depicts the production of more oxygen vacancies [47]. According to the deconvolution data listed in Table 2, the molar ratio of Co2+/Co3+ decreased in the order N-Co3O4–0.15 (1.29) > N-Co3O4–0.05 (1.25) > N-Co3O4–0.01 (1.12) > Co3O4 (0.98). Therefore, N-doping facilitated the introduction of anionic defects or produced more oxygen vacancies for the N-Co3O4-x samples, especially for the N-Co3O4–0.05 and N-Co3O4–0.15 samples. The fitted O 1s spectra of Co3O4 and N-Co3O4-x catalysts (Fig. 9(B)) shows two contributions centered at 529.2–529.7 eV and 530.8–531.3 eV. The lower BE (529.2–529.8 eV) is assigned to the lattice oxygen (Olatt), whereas the higher BE (530.8–531.3 eV) is assigned to the surface oxygen (Osurf) [14]. It can be observed that the BE positions of these two oxygen species in all the N-Co3O4-x catalysts were lower than those of Co3O4. This is due to the difference in electronegativity between N and O elements, which resulted to the increase in outer electron density of O, and the decrease in BE. This phenomenon confirms the viability of doping Co3O4 with N [30]. Surface oxygen species are normally adsorbed on the oxygen vacancies, so the content of this specie determines the number of oxygen vacancies present [50]. From Table 2, the Osurf/(Olatt+Osurf) ratios of these samples followed the sequence N-Co3O4–0.15 (0.35) > N-Co3O4–0.05 (0.33) > N-Co3O4–0.01 (0.30) > Co3O4 (0.27), further revealing that more defects or oxygen vacancies existed in the N-Co3O4-x samples compared to Co3O4. The N 1s spectra of N-Co3O4-x samples as displayed in Fig. 9(C) show that all the samples exhibited weak and diffuse N 1s peaks because of the low N contents. The peak at ~399.6 eV was attributed to Co-N (Nα), while the peak at ~406.7 eV was ascribed to molecularly chemisorbed nitrogen or NO2-type species (Nβ), as observed in N-doped TiO2, CoOx/N-doped CeO2, and N-doped CeO2 [30,51,52]. Furthermore, the ratios of Nβ/Nα were calculated and listed in Table 2, and the table shows that the value of N-Co3O4–0.15 (1.71) was larger than that of N-Co3O4–0.01 (1.53), and much larger than that of N-Co3O4–0.05 (0.97). This is a further confirmation of N-doping in Co3O4; more molecularly chemisorbed nitrogen or NO2-type species existed on the surface of N-Co3O4–0.15, which can potentially cover the active sites and further impede the deN2O reaction. H2-TPR, O2-TPD, EPR, and CO2-TPD tests The reducibility of the pristine Co3O4 and N-Co3O4-x (x = 0.01, 0.05, and 0.15) catalysts were studied by H2-TPR analysis. Fig. 10 (A) reveals that the pristine Co3O4 showed a wide H2 consumption peak in the range of 200–500 °C, which was due to the stepwise reduction of Co3O4, namely; the reductions of Co3+ to Co2+ (low-temperature peak at ~200 °C) and Co2+ to Co0 (medium-temperature peak β at ~400 °C) [15]. For the N-Co3O4-x catalysts, similar peaks attributed to the reduction of Co3O4 were still observed, but with slight changes in position. It is clear that the peak shifted towards low temperatures and then remained unchanged with the increase in x for the N-Co3O4-x catalysts, where such shifts indicate that a proper amount of N-doping contributed to promoting the reducibility of neighboring Co species. Additionally, the total hydrogen consumption in the temperature range of 200–500 °C was estimated and compared with the theoretical values. As listed in Table S1, firstly, the actual amounts of hydrogen consumption required for the reduction of the N-Co3O4-x catalysts were higher compared to the amount required for the reduction of the pristine Co3O4, particularly for the N-Co3O4–0.15 samples. This “extra H2” may be related to the reduction of Co-N species and the decomposition of molecularly chemisorbed nitrogen or NO2-type species existing on the sample surface. Secondly, the actual amounts of hydrogen consumption for the N-Co3O4-x catalysts were obviously lower than the theoretical values, indicating that the crystal structure of g-C3N4 was destroyed during the catalyst preparation process, and a small number of N atoms were doped into the Co3O4, which is consistent with the XRD, FT-IR, and XPS results. Thirdly, there is no obvious correlation between the actual amounts of hydrogen consumption related to N-Co3O4-x reduction. In short, N-doping improved the redox property of Co3O4 and increased the oxygen mobility, proving that N weakened the Co-O bond. Generally, O2 in gas phase is easily absorbed by the oxygen vacancies of the catalysts to form O2 − and O− [53]; thus, the oxygen vacancies of the prepared catalysts were further evaluated by O2-TPD. As shown in Fig. 10(B), two O2 desorption peaks were observed at 50–230 °C and above 350 °C in the Co3O4 and N-Co3O4-x (x = 0.01, 0.05, and 0.15) profiles. The former broad peaks are ascribed to the desorption of Osurf, which refers to O2 − and O− species, while the latter peaks belong to the desorption of surface Olatt [18]. Comparatively, the N-Co3O4 -x catalysts exhibited larger desorption peak areas from 50 to 230 °C than the pristine Co3O4. Furthermore, the amounts of accumulated O2 for the peaks over these catalysts were estimated, and the values are 35.1, 46.6, 71.3, and 65.5 μmol g− 1 for Co3O4, N-Co3O4–0.01, N-Co3O4–0.05, and N-Co3O4–0.15, respectively. Therefore, N-doping induced more anionic defects or oxygen vacancies for the N-Co3O4 -x samples compared with the Co3O4 sample, and N-Co3O4–0.05 had the highest adsorption capacity for O2. Additionally, the peak temperatures of N-Co3O4 -x above 350 °C, shifted to lower values and the corresponding peak areas appear to have decreased with increasing content of x from 0.01 to 0.15, indicating that more N atoms were doped into Co3O4 and the desorption of surface Olatt was facilitated. According to the above characterization results, N-doping is capable of inducing more defects or oxygen vacancies in cobalt oxide. As further proof, EPR tests of the Co3O4 and N-Co3O4–0.05 catalysts were carried out. From Fig. 10(C), a strong EPR signal was observed at g = 2.004, which corresponds to the oxygen vacancies [54]. It is obvious that the peak intensity for N-Co3O4–0.05 significantly increased after N-doping, and was 1.7 times that of the Co3O4 catalyst. The higher intensity of EPR signal unambiguously demonstrates that more defects or oxygen vacancies existed in the N-Co3O4–0.05 sample. These results further prove that doping N into Co3O4 can contribute to the formation of oxygen vacancies. The importance of the surface basicity of the material has been demonstrated in the deN2O reaction, which plays a key role in donating electrons to N2O molecules [7,24,55]. To study the surface basicity of the catalysts, CO2-TPD experiments were performed over the Co3O4 and N-Co3O4 -x (x = 0.01, 0.05, and 0.15) catalysts, and as presented in Fig. 10(D), the results show two CO2 desorption peaks at 100–550 °C for the samples. The first desorption peaks obtained at ~100 °C correspond to the desorption of CO2 uptake on the weak basic sites, while the second peaks above 350 °C are ascribed to the desorption of CO2 uptake on the strong basic sites, such as Co-N species [7]. All the N-Co3O4 -x catalysts exhibited larger total CO2 desorption areas compared with the pristine Co3O4 in the temperature range of this study. Generally, the peak area correlates with the amount of basic sites produced in the synthetic processes of the materials. Hence, the results from CO2-TPD analysis indicate that the N-Co3O4-x catalysts possessed more amounts of total basic sites on their surfaces than Co3O4, and this is also confirmed by the calculated values of the total basic sites given in Table 3 . Table 3 also shows that the amount of strong-strength basic sites and total basic sites on the surfaces of the N-Co3O4 -x samples increased with increasing content of x from 0.01 to 0.15, indicating that more N atoms were doped into Co3O4 to form Co-N species. The N-Co3O4–0.05 and N-Co3O4–0.15 samples contained the most abundant basic sites in this series. Conductivity tests A previous work by Abu-Zied et al. [56] found that the deN2O activities of Pr, Sm, and Tb-promoted CuO catalysts were closely related to their electrical conductivities. The added promoters improved the electron donation abilities of the active centers of CuO catalyst, and further enhanced the N2O adsorption and decomposition. Table 3 lists the conductivities of the Co3O4 and N-Co3O4-x (x = 0.01, 0.05, and 0.15) catalysts, and the values are 4.9 × 10−5, 13.1 × 10−5, 23.5 × 10−5, and 29.7 × 10−5 Ω−1 cm−1 for Co3O4, N-Co3O4–0.01, N-Co3O4–0.05, and N-Co3O4–0.15, respectively. A noticeable increase in conductivity with increasing content of x for the N-Co3O4-x catalysts was observed, and this could be attributed to the difference in electronegativity between N and O, which ensured more electron mobility for the N-Co3O4-x catalysts compared to the Co3O4 catalyst, especially for the N-Co3O4–0.05 and N-Co3O4–0.15 samples. These findings are in agreement with the results of CO2-TPD experiments. Catalytic activity (For the feed gas of 1000 ppm N2O/Ar with various compositions) and stability The obtained deN2O activity of N-Co3O4–0.05 was compared with those reported for other modified Co3O4 catalysts as shown in Table 4 . The table presents the catalysts compositions, reaction conditions, feed gas compositions, and reaction temperatures of 100% N2O conversion. Although it seems challenging to make accurate comparisons among these catalysts under different conditions, N-Co3O4–0.05 is shown to be a highly active catalyst for deN2O. It is possible to infer that the co-doping of N atoms with some other additives like K, Ce, and Y holds great potentials in promoting the production of oxygen vacancies and electron migration, which may further improve the deN2O activity of Co3O4 catalyst. For the feed gas of 1000 ppm N2O/Ar with various compositions Generally, various compositions such as O2, NO, and/or H2O inevitably co-exist in industrial tail gas and often interfere with the deN2O reaction [15,49,53,63,70]; thus, it is necessary to study the inhibition effects of these compositions on the activities of the obtained catalysts. Inspection of Fig. 11 reveals that the activity curves of N-Co3O4–0.05 and Co3O4 were both shifted towards higher temperatures, indicating that the presence of these compositions in the feed lowered the catalytic activities. Specifically, N2O conversions were 100 and 20% over N-Co3O4–0.05 and Co3O4 at 400 °C in the absence of these compositions, whereas in the presence of 3.3 vol.% H2O, they decreased to 96 and 14%, respectively. When 3 vol.% O2 was introduced into the feed gas, N2O conversions over the two catalysts became 97 and 15%, respectively. With the introduction of 200 ppm NO into the feed gas, N2O conversion over N-Co3O4–0.05 was 90%, while that over Co3O4 was only 3%. Particularly, when 3.3 vol.% H2O and 3 vol.% O2 co-existed in the feed gas, N2O conversion over N-Co3O4–0.05 was 86%, while that over Co3O4 was near zero at 400 °C. Note that the effects of the above compositions on deN2O over N-Co3O4–0.05 were smaller than that over Co3O4. Similar phenomena were observed over the two catalysts when 3.3 vol.% H2O + 200 ppm NO co-existed in the feed gas. Therefore, the N-Co3O4–0.05 catalyst exhibited higher resistance to the impurity gasses for deN2O reaction compared to Co3O4. Catalytic stability In addition to catalytic activity, stability is another important parameter that is used to evaluate the performance of catalysts; thus, N2O conversions with reaction time were tested over the N-Co3O4–0.05 and Co3O4 catalysts at 500 °C under the condition of co-existing 3 vol.% O2 in the feed gas. From Fig. 12 , it is clear that the pristine Co3O4 displayed quite an unstable catalytic activity. Its initial catalytic activity (~60%) was maintained only for 8 h, and then it gradually decreased with time. The N2O conversion decreased to 50% from the original 60% after 30 h and then remained stable from 30 h to 40 h. In contrast, the N-Co3O4–0.05 catalyst showed a stable catalytic activity, and the 100% N2O conversion was maintained for at least 40 h. Furthermore, the stability of N-Co3O4–0.05 was evaluated at 500 °C under the condition of co-existing 200 ppm NO or 3.3 vol.% H2O in the feed gas (see Fig. S3). The results obtained herein were consistent with those at 500 °C under the condition of co-existing 3 vol.% O2 in the feed gas. Comparatively, the N-Co3O4–0.05 catalyst exhibited much higher stability and stronger resistance to impurity gasses than Co3O4. As a further test of the stability of the N-Co3O4–0.05 catalyst, the effects of impurity gasses on the N-Co3O4–0.05 were additionally investigated by a step-change experiment at 380 °C. As depicted in Fig. 13 (red line), during the initial 90 min of the reaction, the N2O conversion was stable and maintained at 100%. Upon the addition of 3.3 vol.% H2O into the feed stream, the N2O conversion declined from the initial value (100%) to 88%. After removal of H2O, the N2O conversion was restored back to 100%. In the next step, the introduction of 3.3 vol.% H2O and 3 vol.% O2 to the feed stream reduced the N2O conversion to 78%. Surprisingly, the catalyst activity recovered again after the supply of impurities were shut off. The above experiment was repeated in several cycles and the test results are consistent with the aforementioned findings. As shown in Fig. 13 (blue line), the N-Co3O4–0.05 catalyst also showed fairly stable catalytic activity, where the feed gas (1000 ppm N2O/Ar) was switched at regular intervals to 1000 ppm N2O/Ar containing 200 ppm NO or 3.3 vol.% H2O + 200 ppm NO. To sum up, the stability tests indicate that the N-Co3O4–0.05 exhibited superior stability for deN2O even with the presence of some impurities in the feed. Kinetics of the reaction over Co3O4 and N-Co3O4–0.05 Several studies have confirmed that the deN2O reaction is a first-order reaction [18,26,49]. On this basis, the reaction rate (r) and the corresponding rate constant (k) of N-Co3O4–0.05 and Co3O4 catalysts were calculated, and the values are summarized in Table 5 . It is apparent that N-Co3O4–0.05 had much larger r and k values than Co3O4 at definite reaction temperature, for example, r and k were calculated to be 0.30 μmol s− 1 g− 1 and 1.77 × 10−5 m3 s− 1 g− 1 for N-Co3O4–0.05 at 360 °C, i.e. 17.6 and 41.5 times those of the Co3O4 catalyst. Generally, the activation energy (Ea) is a reflection of the threshold barrier averaged out on all the reaction pathways, which provides an indirect evidence for the intrinsic catalytic ability [57]. Fig. 14 shows the Arrhenius plots for the deN2O reaction over the prepared N-Co3O4–0.05 and Co3O4 catalysts, and Ea was estimated from the slope. The Ea of Co3O4 was 115.4 kJ mol−1, which was much larger than that of N-Co3O4–0.05 (94.2 kJ mol−1). Lower Ea value for N-Co3O4–0.05 translates to improved ease for molecular activation and conversion of N2O, which is attributed to the effect of N-doping. As described in O2-TPD characterization, Co3O4, N-Co3O4–0.01, N-Co3O4–0.05, and N-Co3O4–0.15 desorbed ca. 35, 47, 72, and 66 μmol g− 1 O2 when the temperature was lower than 300 °C. Thus, the population of oxygen vacancies 70, 94, 144, and 132 μmol g − 1 for these samples that could be reproduced at 300 °C by the Eq. (5). These part of oxygen vacancies could be worked in the catalytic cycle of deN2O Eq. (5)-(6). Based on this, TOF of the deN2O reaction over these samples were calculated, and it shows that the reaction occurred with 3.5 × 10−5 s− 1over Co3O4 at 300 °C, 5.3 × 10−5 s− 1over N-Co3O4–0.01, 2.7 × 10−4 s− 1over N-Co3O4–0.05, and 1.9 × 10−5 s− 1 over N-Co3O4–0.15. All these results fully demonstrate the excellent activity of N-Co3O4–0.05 for deN2O compared to other catalysts. Discussion Based on the XRD, FT-IR, Raman, XPS, and EPR experiments, it was confirmed that N atoms were doped into Co3O4, whereas the Co3O4 spinel structures were maintained after the N-doping. N2-physisorption analysis indicated that doping N into Co3O4 facilitated the increase of both S BET and V total, and helped expose the surface of the N-Co3O4–0.05 catalyst, enabling high accessibility of the reactant gas (N2O) to the active sites. Furthermore, the presence of N atoms promoted the amount of surface Co2+ on the N-Co3O4–0.05 as confirmed by the Raman and XPS results. Moreover, after a few N atoms were introduced into the cobalt oxide, more anionic defects or oxygen vacancies in the N-Co3O4–0.05 were created, which enhanced the adsorption of more molecules. The results from XPS, O2-TPD, and EPR offer direct evidence for this observation. Besides, H2-TPR and conductivity tests suggested that N-doping improved the electron donation abilities of Co2+ and Co2+↔Co3+ redox potential of the N-Co3O4–0.05 catalyst, causing the weakening of the Co-O bond. CO2-TPD also indicated that the presence of N atoms after doping contributed to improving the amounts of basic sites; thus, the capability of electron transfer from the sample surface to N2O domains was improved and the activation of N2O molecules was further facilitated. All these factors endowed the N-Co3O4–0.05 catalyst with a lower Ea for deN2O. Thus, the N-Co3O4–0.05 catalyst exhibited superior activity towards deN2O compared to the pristine Co3O4 and N-Co3O4–0.01. Based on the above characterization results, N-Co3O4–0.15 is expected to offer high performance because of its relatively larger S BET, defective structure (oxygen vacancies), surface Co2+, and basic sites on the catalyst, which however is not the case. The results obtained from XPS indicated that more Nβ were formed on the surface of N-Co3O4–0.15, which is capable of covering the active sites, thus causing the degradation of the catalytic deN2O. Besides, the activity tests also showed that the activity of N-Co3O4–0.15 increased rapidly with increase in temperature, and its N2O conversion was the same with that of N-Co3O4–0.01 at 480 °C. This may be due to the decomposition of Nβ at higher temperatures. Thus, the catalytic performance of N-Co3O4–0.15 is mainly dependent on its surface and structural properties, rather than its textural properties. Previous studies have shown that NO, H2O, and O2 inhibit the deN2O reaction in different ways [37,59,71–73]. According to the deN2O mechanism over Co3O4, H2O easily binds to the oxygen vacancy sites; thus, the active sites are hydroxylated, thereby preventing oxygen transfer. However, NO exhibits a competitive oxidation effect by consuming the labile oxygen and decelerating the regeneration of Co2+ and Co3+. NO can also exhibit some competitive adsorption and deactivation through nitrite and nitrate formation. Additionally, O2 can inhibit the recombination of Co3+-O− and Co-O-Co species, hindering the recovery of Co2+ and Co3+. Moreover, O2 is easily adsorbed on the active sites, forming adsorbed oxygen species, and resultantly hindering the deN2O reaction. Based on the experimental characterization results, N-doping can induce more oxygen vacancies for the N-Co3O4–0.05 catalyst, and enhance the redox cycle of Co2+↔Co3+ over N-Co3O4–0.05. Therefore, N-Co3O4–0.05 showed superior deN2O performance in simulated flue gas compared to Co3O4 catalyst. Conclusions In this study, we successfully prepared the defective N-doped Co3O4 catalysts (N-Co3O4-x) via a facile g-C3N4-modified sol-gel method and further studied their catalytic activities of deN2O reaction. N-doping was an effective strategy for improving the catalytic activity of Co3O4, and its activity was correlated with the content of N-doping, of which N-Co3O4–0.05 exhibited excellent activity, superior stability, and stronger resistance to impurity gasses (O2, NO, and/or H2O) to that of the pristine Co3O4. The systematic characterization results confirmed that N atoms could be doped into Co3O4. N-doping facilitated the creation of defective structure (oxygen vacancies), surface Co2+, and basic sites on the catalyst. Furthermore, introduction of N improved the electron donation ability of Co2+, enlarged the surface area, enhanced the redox property of Co3O4, and weakened the Co-O bond. All these factors endowed the N-Co3O4–0.05 catalyst with a lower Ea for deN2O. However, the excessive N-doped content would accumulate to form more molecularly chemisorbed nitrogen or NO2-type species on the catalyst surface, and these species could cover the active sites and further hampered the deN2O. coredata.dc:description: A series of defective N-doped Co3O4 catalysts, N-Co3O4-x (x = 0.002, 0.01, 0.05, 0.15, and 0.25), were prepared by a facile graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4)-modified sol-gel method, and their catalytic behaviors for N2O decomposition reaction were evaluated. The activity tests indicated that all the N-Co3O4-x catalysts showed superior activity than the pristine Co3O4, and N-Co3O4–0.05 exhibited the best activity with 100% N2O conversion at a reaction temperature of 380 °C, ca. 160 °C lower than that of Co3O4. N-Co3O4–0.05 also showed high catalytic activity and stability in the presence of impurity gasses (O2, NO, and/or H2O) at varying reaction conditions. Based on the employed systematic characterization techniques, the successful doping of N atoms into Co3O4 was confirmed. The N-doping facilitated more defective structures (namely oxygen vacancies), surface Co2+, and basic sites on Co3O4. In addition, N-doping contributed to enlarging the surface area, improving the electron donation ability of Co2+, enhancing the redox property of Co3O4, and weakening the Co-O bond. All these factors promoted the performance of N-Co3O4–0.05 for N2O decomposition. This work provides a simple strategy to construct advanced N-doped Co3O4 material for N2O decomposition applications and other catalytic reactions.
coredata.dc:title: N-doped Co3O4 catalyst with a high efficiency for the catalytic decomposition of N2O
